awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Developing Graphene Superlattices in a Massive-Massless Hybrid Electron System
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: The ability to control the electronic properties of graphene (an atomic layer of carbon) with nanoscale precision is critical for the implementation of graphene-based devices. However, many existing techniques used in traditional semiconductors are much less effective on graphene due to its unique structure. To address this challenge, a fundamental materials study enabling such precision control in graphene is developed in this CAREER award project. Overlapping an artificial periodic electronic structure on top of graphene has been predicted to be an effective approach for such a task. Stemming from a hybrid bilayer system that integrates graphene with complex oxide interfaces, this project focuses on understanding the controlling mechanisms which could lead to an on-demand tuning technique for future innovative graphene-based electronic devices. Taking advantage of the novel technique developed through this research, the project will produce a new class module on "physics in nanoelectronics" with demonstrations and experimental opportunities for students involved. The associated videos and course materials will be shared with the broader education community. Undergraduate students will be involved in both the research project and the development of the class module. In addition the course module and related materials will be adopted by outreach programs tailored for students from underrepresented groups to promote their interest in physics and a future career in science. 

Technical Description: The research goal of this CAREER award is to develop a method of band engineering in graphene, which will support the design of unconventional superlattice-based graphene electronics, and to study its fundamental mechanism. The study is based on both the hybrid bilayer system integrating graphene with LaAlO3(LAO)/SrTiO3(STO) interfaces and the conducting atomic force microscopy (c-AFM) technique. The nanoscale periodic patterns of a two dimensional electron gas (2DEG) reversibly created at the LAO/STO interface using c-AFM are expected to generate reprogrammable superlattice potentials in graphene for desired band modifications. The interactions between the massive regular fermions confined at the LaAlO3/SrTiO3 interfaces and the massless Dirac fermions in graphene are studied. Controlling the proximity effects in graphene/complex oxide heterostructures is expected to give rise to exciting new physics and novel functionalities. In addition, the close coupling between oxides and a high-mobility graphene layer could be very powerful for probing the properties at the oxide interfaces, such as sub-band structures and electron correlations. These studies may help to shed light on some of the unsolved problems in complex oxides.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

In this project, we have developed several novel heterostructures formed between 3D complex oxides and 2D layered materials. In these material systems, the strong correlation between charge, spin, lattice, and other material degrees of freedom leads to highly rich phase diagrams and the possibilities of tailoring artificial quantum functionalities via interfacial coupling. Specifically, a quality hybrid interface between graphene, LaAlO3, and SrTiO3 was successfully fabricated, and a conducting-AFM based technique allowing long-living nanoelectronic structures to be reversibly created and reconfigured was developed.  In this system, the interplay between surface charges, defects, multiple doping mechanisms, and multiple carrier subbands was elucidated. Using the oxide two dimensional electron gas structures, the transport properties of graphene can be flexibly tuned at the nanoscale. We also found that the interaction with the complex oxide substrates renders graphene much more sensitive to defect formations. These defects, created either by surface treatment or high energy photon illumination, can not only alter the quantum transport mechanism in graphene but also effectively control its contact friction state. Taking advantage of the freely patternable potential landscape at such material interfaces, we were able to manipulate the local symmetries and allow either the low density electron gas to effectively couple to free-space light or generate giant photothermoelectric effect at room temperature. Using a similar AFM based direct write method, we also succeeded in realizing reconfigurable nanoscale manipulations of VO2 thin films from the pristine monoclinic semiconducting phase to either a stable monoclinic metallic phase, a metastable rutile metallic phase, or a layered insulating phase, all at room temperature. Additionally, the strong electron-phonon correlations in 3D complex oxides can be used to manipulate the superconductivity pairing in 2D vdW films through interface coupling. We have successfully demonstrated the optical gating in monolayer FeSe/SrTiO3, where a brief exposure to a weak light can raise the superconducting transition temperature by 25%. Using tailored sequence of UV light pulses and voltage pulses applied to the back of the SrTiO3 substrate, the heterostructure can be persistently driven between the metastable superconducting state and its normal ground state, paving the way toward optically controlled active superconducting devices.

Broader impact

This project opens up a new path of making programmable and multifunctional nanodevices using complex oxides that are well-known for the strong electron correlation effects and layer 2D materials that host nascent quantum phases. The results not only demonstrate the possibility of triggering significant structural and electronic transitions by weak perturbations, but also yields important insight into many fundamental material science problems, such as the limiting factor for carrier mobility in correlated systems and the unconventional pairing mechanism in 2D superconductors. This project also provided valuable training opportunities for three graduate students and two postdocs. All three students have completed their PhD program and landed great jobs in STEM fields. The postdocs have also successfully moved to the next phase of their academic research career. Supported by this project, the PI was able to develop new demonstrations for graduate courses, organize outreach workshop for high school teachers and students, serve as judges in local and international STEM affairs (such as Intel ISEF), and give presentations to general public audience. These activities are expected to promote the public awareness of STEM research and encourage the young generation to study or work in STEM fields.
